item.title: UFOs (TV series)
item.description:
UFOs (TV series) ðŸ”—

A French science fiction comedy-drama television series titled UFOs (French: OVNI(s)) created by ClÃ©mence Dargent and Martin Douaire. It premiered on Canal+ on January 11, 2021, and was renewed for a second season before its premiere. The series was cancelled after two seasons on June 30, 2022. Melvil Poupaud stars as a scientist leading a team of UFO researchers in France. It has been compared to a mix of La Soupe aux choux, The Office, and The X-Files.

Plot ðŸ”—

The series follows the investigations of a French UFO research department.

Season 1 ðŸ”—

In 1978, CNES engineer Didier Mathure’s rocket explodes, leading to his demotion to head of GEPAN, a department studying unexplained aerial phenomena. With the help of an eccentric team, he searches for evidence of paranormal and extraterrestrial life in France.

Season 2 ðŸ”—

In 1979, Didier Mathure, now a believer in UFOs after a previous experience, travels France with VÃ©ra in search of supernatural events. He becomes disconnected from his family, while his ex-wife, Ã‰lise, becomes director of CNES. A mysterious event at a nuclear power plant reunites Didier with his former GEPAN colleagues. They attempt to contact extraterrestrial life, observed by Claire Carmignac from the Ministry of Development and Energy.

Cast ðŸ”—

The series features a main cast and recurring actors.

Main ðŸ”—

  • Melvil Poupaud as Didier Mathure
  • Michel Vuillermoz as Marcel BÃ©nes
  • GÃ©raldine Pailhas as Ã‰lise Conti
  • Quentin Dolmaire as RÃ©my Bidaut
  • DaphnÃ© Patakia as VÃ©ra Clouseau
  • Nicole Garcia as ValÃ©rie Delbrosse
  • Alice Taglioni as Claire Carmignac

Recurring ðŸ”—

  • AndrÃ©a FerrÃ©ol as Suzanne, Didier’s mother

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of two seasons, each containing 12 episodes.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

The first season’s 12 episodes were directed by Antony Cordier and written by ClÃ©mence Dargent and Martin Douaire, with contributions from Julien Anscutter, Marie Eynard, Clemence Madeleine Perdrillet, and RaphaÃ«lle Richet. The episodes were originally released between January 11, 2021, and February 1, 2021.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

The second season’s 12 episodes were directed by Antony Cordier and written by ClÃ©mence Dargent, Martin Douaire, and Maxime Berthemy, with collaboration from RaphaÃ«lle Richet. The episodes were originally released between February 21, 2022, and March 14, 2022.

Awards ðŸ”—

The series has received recognition at the ACS Awards.

  • ACS Awards
    • Best TV Series: 26 minutes (2021)
    • Best Actor for Melvil Poupaud (2021)
    • Best Director for Antony Cordier (2022)

External links ðŸ”—

  • UFOs at IMDb

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFOs_(TV_series)

item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive description of the Wikipedia article for the American television series Resident Alien.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a brief introduction to the television series Resident Alien. It establishes the show’s genre as a science fiction mystery comedy-drama and identifies Chris Sheridan as the creator. It also mentions that the show is based on the comic book series of the same name by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse. The premiere date of the first season on Syfy is noted, along with the star, Alan Tudyk. The renewals for subsequent seasons, including the move to USA Network for the fourth season, are also mentioned.

Premise ðŸ”—

This section outlines the central plot of the series. An alien arrives on Earth with the mission to wipe out humanity. After crashing in Colorado, the alien assumes the identity of a doctor named Harry Vanderspeigle. As he lives among humans, he begins to question his mission. A young boy, Max Hawthorne, can see through his disguise. The alien grapples with his mission and ultimately defends humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

This section details the main and recurring cast members and their respective characters.

Main ðŸ”—

  • Alan Tudyk plays the alien, who takes on the identity of Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle. He is sent to Earth to destroy humanity but develops compassion. Tudyk also portrays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle.
  • Sara Tomko plays Asta Twelvetrees, the assistant to the town doctor and a member of the Ute tribe. She is the first person after Max to discover Harry’s true identity.
  • Corey Reynolds plays Sheriff Mike Thompson, the town’s sheriff, who is dealing with past trauma.
  • Alice Wetterlund plays D’arcy Bloom, the owner of the town pub and Asta’s best friend. She discovers Harry’s true identity after learning that the real Harry killed Sam Hodges.
  • Levi Fiehler plays Ben Hawthorne, the town’s mayor, who has a history of alien abductions.
  • Judah Prehn plays Max Hawthorne, Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen plays Deputy Liv Baker, the town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrials.

Recurring ðŸ”—

This section lists actors and the recurring characters they portray, including:

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest ðŸ”—

This section lists actors and the guest characters they portray, including:

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, broken down by season.

Series overview ðŸ”—

This subsection presents a table summarizing the number of episodes per season, the original release dates, and the network on which each season aired.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 10 episodes of the first season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 16 episodes of the second season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot. The season is split into two parts, each with eight episodes.

Season 3 (2024) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 8 episodes of the third season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the development, casting, and filming aspects of the series.

Development ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the origins of the series, stating that Chris Sheridan was inspired by the novels and comic book series of the same name. It also mentions Sheridan’s personal experience with a UFO sighting as inspiration. The initial pilot order by Syfy, along with the involvement of Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television, is mentioned. The series order, production location in Vancouver, and David Dobkin’s role as director and executive producer are also noted.

Casting ðŸ”—

This subsection lists the initial casting announcements, including Alan Tudyk as the lead, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. It also mentions the casting of Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, Alex Barima, and Elizabeth Bowen in recurring roles.

Filming ðŸ”—

This subsection provides information on the filming locations and timelines for each season. Principal photography for the first season took place in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. Filming details for the second and third seasons are also included.

Release ðŸ”—

This section details the release dates of the series. Syfy initially announced a summer 2020 premiere, which was later moved to January 2021. International premiere dates in Canada and the United Kingdom are also mentioned.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical response ðŸ”—

This subsection presents the review scores from Rotten Tomatoes and Metacritic for the first and second seasons, highlighting the positive critical reception.

Ratings ðŸ”—

This subsection provides a table with viewership and ratings per episode for the first season.

Accolades ðŸ”—

This section lists the awards and nominations received by the series, including those from the Saturn Awards, Critics Choice Super Awards, Dragon Awards, and Hollywood Critics Association Television Awards.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section provides clarifying information and context for certain details within the article, such as character name spellings, guest star credits, and rating metrics.

References ðŸ”—

This section contains a list of citations used throughout the article, providing sources for the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to the official website and the IMDb page for the series.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Futurama
item.description:
Futurama ðŸ”—

A 1999 American animated science fiction sitcom created by Matt Groening.

Genre ðŸ”—

Animated sitcom, science fiction, and satire.

Created by ðŸ”—

Matt Groening.

Developed by ðŸ”—

Matt Groening and David X. Cohen.

Voices of ðŸ”—

Billy West, Katey Sagal, John DiMaggio, Tress MacNeille, Maurice LaMarche, Phil LaMarr, Lauren Tom, and David Herman.

Opening theme ðŸ”—

“Theme from Futurama” composed by Christopher Tyng.

Country of origin ðŸ”—

United States.

Original language ðŸ”—

English.

Number of seasons ðŸ”—

9

Number of episodes ðŸ”—

160

Executive producers ðŸ”—

Matt Groening, David X. Cohen, Ken Keeler, and Claudia Katz.

Producers ðŸ”—

Lew Morton, J. Stewart Burns, Patric M. Verrone, Bill Odenkirk, Eric Kaplan, Michael Rowe, Brian J. Cowan, Jason Grode, Jane O’Brien, and Lee Supercinski.

Editors ðŸ”—

Paul D. Calder, Danik Thomas, and Chris Vallance.

Production companies ðŸ”—

The Curiosity Company, 20th Century Fox Television (seasons 1â€“7), and 20th Television Animation (season 8â€“present).

Original release ðŸ”—

  • Fox: March 28, 1999 â€“ August 10, 2003
  • Comedy Central: March 23, 2008 â€“ September 4, 2013
  • Hulu: July 24, 2023 â€“ present

Premise ðŸ”—

The series follows Philip J. Fry, a pizza delivery boy who is cryogenically preserved for 1,000 years and revived on December 31, 2999. Fry finds work at the interplanetary delivery company Planet Express, working alongside the one-eyed mutant Leela and the robot Bender. Groening envisioned the series in the mid-1990s while working on The Simpsons, and brought David X. Cohen aboard to develop storylines and characters.

Characters ðŸ”—

The plot revolves around the Planet Express interplanetary delivery company and its employees. Episodes usually feature the central trio of Fry, Leela, and Bender, though occasional storylines center on the other main characters.

  • Philip J. Fry: Voiced by Billy West, Fry is an immature, slovenly, yet good-hearted pizza delivery boy who is cryogenically frozen for 1,000 years.
  • Turanga Leela: Voiced by Katey Sagal, Leela is the competent, one-eyed captain of the Planet Express Ship.
  • Bender Bending Rodriguez: Voiced by John DiMaggio, Bender is a foul-mouthed, heavy-drinking, cigar-smoking, kleptomaniacal, misanthropic, egocentric, ill-tempered robot.
  • Professor Hubert J. Farnsworth: Voiced by Billy West, Professor Farnsworth is Fry’s distant nephew and the founder of Planet Express Inc.
  • Hermes Conrad: Voiced by Phil LaMarr, Hermes is the Jamaican accountant of Planet Express.
  • Dr. John A. Zoidberg: Voiced by Billy West, Zoidberg is a Decapodian and the neurotic staff physician of Planet Express.
  • Amy Wong: Voiced by Lauren Tom, Amy is an incredibly rich, blunt, ditzy, and accident-prone intern at Planet Express.

Setting ðŸ”—

Futurama is set in New New York at the turn of the 31st century. The city of New New York has been built over the ruins of present-day New York City, which has become a catacomb-like space that acts as New New York’s sewer, referred to as “Old New York”. Parts of the sewers are inhabited by mutants. Various devices and architecture are similar to the Populuxe style. Global warming, inflexible bureaucracy, and substance abuse are a few of the subjects given a 31st-century exaggeration.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The list of episodes follows the season box sets, which feature the episodes in the original production season order, ignoring the order of broadcast. The Hulu revival has alternatively been titled the eighth and ninth seasons (production), and the eleventh and twelfth seasons (broadcast). The tenth and eleventh production seasons will also be considered as Futurama’s thirteenth and fourteenth broadcast seasons.

Season Episodes Originally released Network
1 13 March 28, 1999 â€“ November 14, 1999 Fox
2 19 November 21, 1999 â€“ December 3, 2000 Fox
3 22 January 21, 2001 â€“ December 8, 2002 Fox
4 18 February 10, 2002 â€“ August 10, 2003 Fox
5 16 March 23, 2008 â€“ August 30, 2009 Comedy Central
6 26 June 24, 2010 â€“ September 8, 2011 Comedy Central
7 26 June 20, 2012 â€“ September 4, 2013 Comedy Central
8 10 July 24, 2023 â€“ September 25, 2023 Hulu
9 10 July 29, 2024 â€“ September 30, 2024 Hulu

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

Fox expressed a strong desire in the mid-1990s for Matt Groening to create a new series after the success of The Simpsons. In 1995, he enlisted David X. Cohen to assist in developing the show. When they pitched the series to Fox in April 1998, Groening and Cohen had composed many characters and story lines. Fox ordered thirteen episodes. Fox feared the themes of the show were not suitable for the network and Groening and Fox executives argued over whether the network would have any creative input into the show. The episode “I, Roommate” was produced to address Fox’s concerns. The name Futurama comes from a pavilion at the 1939 New York World’s Fair.

Writing ðŸ”—

The planning for each episode began with a table meeting of writers, who discussed the plot ideas as a group. A single staff writer wrote an outline and then produced a script. Once the first draft of a script was finished, the writers and executive producers called in the actors for a table read. After this script reading, the writers collaborated to rewrite the script as a group before sending it to the animation team. The writing staff held three Ph.D.s, seven master’s degrees, and cumulatively had more than 50 years at Harvard University.

Voice actors ðŸ”—

Futurama had eight main cast members. Billy West performed the voices of Philip J. Fry, Professor Farnsworth, Doctor Zoidberg, Zapp Brannigan, and many other incidental characters. Katey Sagal voiced Leela, and is the only member of the main cast to voice only one character. John DiMaggio performed the voice of the robot Bender Bending RodrÃ­guez and other, more minor, characters. Phil LaMarr voices Hermes Conrad, his son Dwight, Ethan Bubblegum Tate, and Reverend Preacherbot. Lauren Tom voices Amy Wong, and Tress MacNeille voices Mom and various other characters. Maurice LaMarche voices Kif Kroker and several supporting characters. David Herman voiced Scruffy and various supporting characters.

Animation ðŸ”—

Futurama is produced by The Curiosity Company and 20th Television Animation with the animation being done by Rough Draft Studios. In addition to traditional cartoon drawing, Rough Draft Studios often used CGI for fast or complex shots. The series began high-definition production in season 6, with Bender’s Big Score. For the final episode of season 6, Futurama was completely reanimated in three different styles: Fleischer- and Walter Lantz-style animation, a low-resolution video game, and Japanese anime.

Hallmarks ðŸ”—

Opening sequence ðŸ”—

The Planet Express Ship flies across the screen with the title of the show being spelled out in its wake. Underneath the title is a joke caption. After flying through downtown New New York and past various recurring characters, the Planet Express ship crashes through a large screen showing a short clip from a classic cartoon. The Futurama theme was created by Christopher Tyng.

Languages ðŸ”—

There are three alternative alphabets that appear often in the background of episodes. The first alphabet consists of abstract characters and is referred to as Alienese, a simple substitution cipher from the Latin alphabet. The second alphabet uses a more complex modular addition code. The third language sometimes used is Hebrew. The show predicts that several English expressions will have evolved by the year 3000

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alienese

item.title: Roswell (film)
item.description:
Roswell (film) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1994 American science fiction television film Roswell, also known as Roswell: The U.F.O. Cover-Up. The film is based on the alleged Roswell UFO incident, which involves the U.S. military’s supposed capture of a flying saucer and its alien crew after a crash near Roswell, New Mexico, in July 1947. The film also references other UFOlogy events, including Area 51, alien autopsies, the death of James Forrestal, and Majestic-12.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot unfolds through flashbacks at a 30-year reunion of the 509th Operations Group. It centers on Major Jesse Marcel’s investigation into strange debris found on a rancher’s field in July 1947. Despite being told by his superiors that it was merely a downed weather balloon, Marcel persists in his search for the truth, ultimately uncovering the reality of what occurred. Key figures include Major Jesse Marcel and the setting is Roswell, New Mexico.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times. The New York Times praised the film’s tense drama but questioned the plausibility of a long-term cover-up. Variety called it a gripping fictional account and highlighted the convincing pacing and unflinching portrayal of military mendacity. The Los Angeles Times viewed the film as more than just a sci-fi story, focusing on the protagonist’s search for truth.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Kyle MacLachlan as Jesse A. Marcel, Martin Sheen as Townsend, and Dwight Yoakam as Mac Brazel. Other notable cast members include Xander Berkeley, Bob Gunton, Kim Greist, Peter MacNicol, John M. Jackson, and Nick Searcy. The cast also features appearances by Charles Hallahan, Ray McKinnon, Eugene Roche, and Charles Martin Smith.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the citations used in the article, including reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the film’s entry on the IMDb (Internet Movie Database) website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_(film)

item.title: Alien Apocalypse (2005 film)
item.description:
Alien Apocalypse (2005 film) ðŸ”—

This entry describes the 2005 American science fiction TV film Alien Apocalypse.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section presents the film’s promotional poster and basic information in a table format. Key details include:

  • Writer and Director: Josh Becker
  • Starring: Bruce Campbell, Renee O’Connor, Remington Franklin, Michael Cory Davis, and Peter Jason
  • Theme Music Composer: Joseph LoDuca
  • Country of Origin: United States
  • Language: English
  • Production: Jeff Franklin and Bob Perkis
  • Cinematography: David Worth
  • Editor: Shawn Paper
  • Production Company: Syfy
  • Original Release: March 26, 2005
  • Network: Sci Fi Channel

It establishes the film as a Sci Fi Channel original movie.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot summary details the events of the film:

  • Astronaut Dr. Ivan Hood (Bruce Campbell) and his companion Kelly return to Earth after a 40-year space mission.
  • They discover Earth has been conquered by giant termite-like aliens who used EMP bombs to disable the planet 20 years prior.
  • Humans are enslaved and forced to work in camps.
  • Dr. Hood and Kelly are captured near the ruins of Portland, Oregon.
  • They plan an escape after learning of a surviving President.
  • Kelly is recaptured, and Dr. Hood seeks out the President, eventually finding him a broken man.
  • Dr. Hood rallies escaped slaves to attack the alien camp and rescue Kelly.
  • The attack is successful with the help of the President’s forces.
  • Dr. Hood becomes known as “The Great Exterminator” and continues to fight the aliens.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the film:

  • Bruce Campbell as Dr. Ivan Hood
  • Renee O’Connor as Lieutenant Kelly Lanaman
  • Remington Franklin as Alex
  • Michael Cory Davis as Captain Chuck Burkes
  • Peter Jason as President Demsky
  • Vladimir Kolev as Bob “Fisherman Bob”
  • Valentin Giasbeily as Tyler
  • Velizar Binev as Manager
  • Dimiter Kuzov as Bounty Hunter 1
  • Krum Iapulov as Bounty Hunter 2
  • Jonas Talkington as Bounty Hunter 3
  • Zlatko Zlatkov as Bounty Hunter 4
  • Chavdar Simeonov as Alien Leader
  • Anton Trendafilov as Jeff
  • Rosi Chernogova as Bizzy
  • Todor Nikolov as Bill “Mountain Man Bill”
  • Asen Blatechki as Crazy Man

Production ðŸ”—

This section provides information about the film’s production:

  • The film was shot in Bulgaria.
  • Many of the actors were Bulgarian and spoke little English, requiring extensive dubbing in post-production.

It includes an image of Josh Becker directing the film.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception of the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse received mixed reviews from critics and audiences.
  • David Nusair of Reel Film Reviews noted that the film doesn’t take itself seriously, especially by the end.

See also ðŸ”—

This section lists other films with similar themes:

  • Planet of the Apes (1968)
  • Battlefield Earth
  • Android Apocalypse

References ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external sources used in the article:

  1. DVD Talk review
  2. Reel Film Reviews article

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse at IMDb
  • “The Making of Alien Apocalypse” by Josh Becker
  • The shooting script for Alien Apocalypse

A navigation template for films directed by Josh Becker is also included.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Apocalypse

item.title: Alien Lockdown (2004 Film)
item.description:
Alien Lockdown (2004 Film) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 2004 American science fiction horror television film Alien Lockdown, directed by Tim Cox. It also goes by the names Creature and Predatorman.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a brief introduction to the film, highlighting its genre as science fiction horror and its alternative titles. It names Tim Cox as the director and Ross Helford and T.M. Van Ostrand as the screenwriters, based on a story by John Thompson, Boaz Davidson, and Kenneth M. Badish. The lead actors, John Savage, James Marshall, and Michelle Goh, are also mentioned.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around an ancient alien life force that awakens and threatens humanity. A SWAT team, led by a skilled assassin, must prevent the alien from consuming humans. The alien had been dormant for centuries, waiting for human knowledge to advance enough to unlock its potential. A mad scientist unlocks the genetic code, leading to the creation of mutant creatures. The military attempts to eliminate the creatures within a top-secret base, but the creature grows stronger with each kill.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the film:

  • John Savage as Dr. Alan Woodman
  • James Marshall as Charlie Dryfus
  • Michelle Goh as Commander Rita Talon
  • T.M. Van Ostrand as Lieutenant Raymond Green
  • Nathan Perez as Sal Meyer
  • David Kallaway as Kerns
  • Martin Kove as Colonel Anslow
  • Atanas Srebrev as Temple
  • Stanimir Stamatov as Hoog
  • Raicho Vasilev as Monie
  • Stanislav Dimitrov as Creature

References ðŸ”—

This section is a placeholder indicating that the article needs citations for verification.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the film’s page on IMDb (Internet Movie Database).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Lockdown

item.title: My Parents Are Aliens
item.description:
My Parents Are Aliens ðŸ”—

My Parents Are Aliens is a British children’s television sitcom created by Andy Watts and produced by Yorkshire Television/Granada Yorkshire. It aired on ITV from November 8, 1999, to December 18, 2006, spanning eight series. The show requires additional citations for verification.

Overview ðŸ”—

The show centers on the lives of orphaned siblings Mel, Josh, and Lucy Barker, who are fostered by Brian and Sophie Johnson. The children discover that their new parents are aliens from the planet Valux who crash-landed on Earth. The house they live in is a morphed form of their spaceship. Brian and Sophie have limited knowledge of Earth customs, and the children help them navigate human life while keeping their alien identities secret. The show’s humor is surreal and subversive, appealing to both children and older viewers.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of 106 episodes across eight series. Series 1 has 6 episodes, Series 2 has 10 episodes, Series 3 has 10 episodes, Series 4 has 13 episodes, Series 5 has 13 episodes, Series 6 has 20 episodes, Series 7 has 20 episodes, and Series 8 has 14 episodes. The episodes aired between November 8, 1999, and December 18, 2006.

Characters ðŸ”—

Parents ðŸ”—

  • Brian Johnson (Tony Gardner): A Valuxian alien and the cause of the crash-landing. He is childlike, amoral, and ignorant of Earth culture but an excellent scientist. He has an allergy to ice cream that causes him to grow moose antlers.
  • Sophie Johnson (Barbara Durkin/Carla MendonÃ§a): Brian’s wife, also a Valuxian alien. She has more common sense than Brian but is still clueless. She can only morph when eating ice cream. Carla MendonÃ§a replaced Barbara Durkin in the role after Sophie morphs into a new shape at the beginning of the third series and is unable to return to her previous form.

Series 1â€“7: The Barkers ðŸ”—

  • Melanie â€˜Melâ€™ Barker (Danielle McCormack): The oldest Barker sibling, a sarcastic teenager with a protective nature. She eventually moves to Canada on an exchange program.
  • Joshua â€˜Joshâ€™ Barker (Alex Kew): The middle sibling, a devious and scheming boy who constantly invents scams.
  • Lucia â€˜Lucyâ€™ Barker (Charlotte Francis): The youngest and most intelligent Barker, excelling in Maths and Science.
  • C.J. (Olisa Odele): An orphan adopted into the family after discovering Brian and Sophie are aliens.
  • Harriet â€˜Harryâ€™ Barker (Stephanie Fearon): Adopted after Mel leaves, similar to Mel in personality.

Other characters ðŸ”—

  • Pete Walker (Patrick Niknejad): One of Josh’s friends.
  • Frankie Perkins (Jordan Maxwell): Another of Josh’s friends.
  • Wendy Richardson (Isabella Melling): Lucy’s friend.
  • Terence â€˜Trentâ€™ Clements (Keith Warwick): Mel’s friend and eventual boyfriend.
  • Mr Graham Whiteside (Dan O’Brien): A grumpy teacher.
  • Mrs Alison Hardman (Beatrice Kelley): Another of Josh’s and Lucy’s teachers.
  • Poppy Manning (Kirsha Southward): A rival to Josh and Lucy.
  • Tania Thomas (Zoe Thorne/Emily Fleeshman/Sasha Tilley): The object of Josh’s affections.
  • Mikey (Chris Cornwell): One of Josh’s friends in the first series.
  • Dave Locket (Julian Triandafyllou): A popular boy in school.
  • Andy â€˜the Freakâ€™ (Danny Robinson): A geeky boy in love with Mel.
  • Scott Taylor (Marco Williamson): A popular boy who Mel had a date with.

Series 8: The Bennetts ðŸ”—

  • Jacqueline â€˜Jaqâ€™ Bennett (Jessica Woods): The oldest of the new foster children.
  • Dan Bennett (Daniel Feltham): Becky’s twin.
  • Becky Bennett (Katie Pearson): Dan’s twin.
  • Eddie Bennett (Jake Young): The youngest member of the family.

Production ðŸ”—

The show was filmed in Studio 4 at The Leeds Studios. A laugh track was added from series 4 onwards. The last episode of series 7 featured the original cast and concluded ongoing plots. Series 8 introduced a new family, the Bennetts, after Brian and Sophie’s memories were erased. ITV closed its in-house children’s production unit, ending the show after series 8. Nickelodeon purchased the rights to make an American version, but the pilot never entered production.

Broadcast ðŸ”—

Series 1 to 7 was repeated regularly on CITV from the channel’s launch in 2006 up until late 2017, while series 8 repeats were discontinued by early 2010. Entertainment Rights Distribution handled worldwide distribution rights to the series.

Home media ðŸ”—

A VHS release containing all six Series One episodes was released in 2000 by Video Collection International and Granada Media. A single-release DVD containing two episodes from Series 2 and four from Series 3 titled The Best Of was released in 2006 by Right Entertainment/Universal Pictures Video UK. Right/Universal also released Series 1 and 2 in a box-set.

Awards and nominations ðŸ”—

The show won a Royal Television Society Award for Best Children’s Drama in 2000 and 2006. It was nominated for a Children’s BAFTA Award for Best Drama in 2001, 2003, and 2004. It also won Best Children’s Program at the Banff Television Festival and Best Children’s Fiction in 2002.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/My_Parents_Are_Aliens

item.title: I Was a Sixth Grade Alien!
item.description:
I Was a Sixth Grade Alien! ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the Canadian-British children’s science fiction comedy television series I Was a Sixth Grade Alien!, also known as My Best Friend is an Alien! in the UK and Australia. The series follows Pleskit, an extraterrestrial with purple skin, blue hair, and an antenna, as he tries to fit in and make friends in sixth grade. He befriends Tim, who is interested in space and aliens. Together, they navigate unusual problems, including a trans-universal portal game and a creature from Pleskit’s home planet. The show premiered on July 13, 1999, and ended on January 10, 2001. It was produced by Winklemania Productions and AAC Kids, with participation from various Canadian funding bodies. The series is based on Bruce Coville’s book series of the same name.

Episode listing ðŸ”—

This section indicates that the series consists of 39 episodes.

Season 1 (1999â€“2000) ðŸ”—

This section lists the episodes of the first season, including titles, directors, writers, and original air dates. Carl Goldstein and Bill Fleming are named as directors, and Sheri Elwood, Cameron Rothery, Derek Schreyer, and John Slama are named as writers. The first episode, “They Called Him Pleskit!”, aired on July 13, 1999, and the season includes episodes such as “Aliens to Blow Up Earth!”, “Alien Dinner Massacre!”, and “Attack of the 1000 Foot Veeblax!”.

Season 2 (2000â€“2001) ðŸ”—

This section lists the episodes of the second season. Some episode titles include “There’s an Alien in My Seat!”, “I Am Larrabe Hicks!”, “Bride of Pleskit!”, and “His Girlfriend Is an Alien!”. It notes that the episode “Escape from Zartopia!” was only shown on YTV in Canada.

References ðŸ”—

This section is a placeholder for references used in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources related to the show, including its IMDb page, an episode guide at epguides.com, and a page on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation website.

Former YTV original programming ðŸ”—

This section is a template listing former original programming broadcast by YTV, including I Was a Sixth Grade Alien! and many other shows from the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s. It also includes links to related topics such as current original series, Corus Entertainment, Nelvana, The Zone, Treehouse TV, Teletoon, and StackTV.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Was_a_Sixth_Grade_Alien!

item.title: Gulf Breeze UFO incident
item.description:
Gulf Breeze UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO incident refers to a series of claimed UFO sightings that occurred in Gulf Breeze, Florida, between November 1987 and May 1988. The events gained widespread attention after the Gulf Breeze Sentinel newspaper published photographs purportedly showing a UFO, provided by local contractor Ed Walters.

Events of November 11, 1987 â€“ May 1, 1988 ðŸ”—

Ed Walters claimed to have been immobilized by a blue beam on November 11, 1987, after which he took photos of a UFO hovering near his home. He reported multiple subsequent encounters, taking more photos and even videotaping the object. Walters also claimed to have witnessed the craft landing and aliens exiting, communicating with him telepathically in English and Spanish, and even being lifted off the ground by a blue beam. He reported a total of nineteen sightings or encounters. On one occasion, he claimed the UFO leaked a liquid that continued to boil for weeks.

Investigation ðŸ”—

Walters initially provided his photographs to the Gulf Breeze Sentinel anonymously. He later admitted to being the photographer and submitted to a polygraph test, which indicated he believed his photos were real. Walters also claimed to have experienced missing time on three prior occasions and under hypnosis, stated he had been abducted by aliens.

Several individuals investigated the claims. Ray Stanford initially questioned the weather data related to the photos but later conceded they were likely taken on the reported day. Phillip Klass dismissed the photos as inauthentic. Robert Nathan from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory suggested the images were double exposures or manipulated. Ed Gray, the mayor of Gulf Breeze, also concluded the photos were fake.

Budd Hopkins believed Walters’ claims were genuine, citing his polygraph test and refusal of a book deal. Bruce Maccabee found a good chance the photos were real. Willy Smith from UNICAT suggested a support under the UFO in the photos indicated it was a model.

Eglin Air Force Base, located near Gulf Breeze, reported no unusual activity or radar blips during the alleged sightings. Gulf Breeze’s police chief, Jerry Brown, attributed the sightings to hysteria and misidentification of activity at the base.

Eyewitness Reports ðŸ”—

Following the publication of Walters’ photos, numerous other residents reported sightings in the Gulf Breeze area. These reports described orange glows, beams of light, and oval or oblong crafts. Fenner McConnell and his wife Shirley claimed to have seen a disc-shaped aircraft with no wings. Brenda Pollak, a Gulf Breeze councilwoman, reported seeing an orange light and witnessed Walters taking photos of a UFO at Shoreline Park. Santa Rosa County Commissioner John Broxson also claimed to have seen unusual lights. Other residents, like Art and Mary Hufford, and Jeff Thompson, reported seeing similar objects. A tollbooth operator, Jerry Thompson, reported seeing thirteen pink-lighted objects.

UFO Research Group Response ðŸ”—

Supporters of Walters, particularly within MUFON, viewed the mass sightings as evidence of the phenomena’s authenticity. MUFON’s director, Walter Andrus, considered the Gulf Breeze incident their “best case ever.” Donald Ware, MUFON’s Florida director, believed the aliens wanted the photos to be seen.

CUFOS, founded by J. Allen Hynek, deemed Walters’ photos fake due to inconsistencies in the craft’s windows and waviness suggesting reflection off water. Friends of Walters reportedly described him as a prankster who had planned “the ultimate prank” and noted parallels between his story and Whitley Streiber’s book Communion.

Model Discovered ðŸ”—

In 1990, a model resembling the UFO in Walters’ photos was found in the attic of his former home. The model was made of foam plates and drafting paper. Craig Myers of the Pensacola News Journal reported the discovery and was able to duplicate Walters’ photos using the model. Walters denied any knowledge of the model, claiming it was planted.

The discovery of the model caused division within the UFO community. Supporters claimed it was planted, while others expressed doubt in Walters’ claims. It was also revealed that Walters had received a $200,000 book advance and was offered $450,000 for miniseries rights. Additionally, he had a prior criminal record for forgery and auto theft, for which he received a pardon from Governor Bob Martinez.

Renewed Interest After 1990 ðŸ”—

UFO sightings continued at the Pensacola Bay Bridge into 1991. In 1993, a friend of the Walters family admitted to witnessing Ed faking the UFO pictures. Mark Curtis also reported that Walter and his wife had divorced in November 1992, splitting $2.5 million in assets believed to have come from the hoax.

MUFON held its first annual UFO symposium in Pensacola in 1990, which continued for the rest of the decade. The publicity attracted tourists and UFO sightseers, boosting the local economy.

In the Media ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO case was featured on Unsolved Mysteries and a TV special called “UFO Cover-UP…Live!”. Eyewitness Shirley McConnell discussed her experience on A Current Affair. Unsolved Mysteries, Inside Edition, and A Current Affair filmed more UFO shows in July 1990.

In a 1994 episode of The X-Files, Fox Mulder mentions the Gulf Breeze UFO photos, stating he knew they were fakes.

Gulf Breeze singer Ken Manning won an award for his song “Gulf Breeze UFO” in 1999.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_Breeze_UFO_incident
